author: peter.davies
content:
The new execution specs has a pull request containing the comment:
```
    # Historical Note: The difficulty bomb was not present in Ethereum at the
    # start of Frontier, but was added shortly after launch. However since the
    # bomb has no effect prior to block 200000 we pretend it existed from
    # genesis.
```
Is anyone who was around in 2015 able to confirm/correct this?

author: pipermerriam
content: You could rewind go-ethereum commit history and look at the diff between the timestamps of genesis and block 200000.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't *think* that would answer the question?  It is expected that a diff of a client will show a change in behavior around block 200,000.  The question here I believe is whether there is anything wrong with just pretending that change was in there from the start, or if it would work just fine from a consensus point of view.

author: pipermerriam
content: If you look at genesis code and there is no `if block.number > 200000` in the difficulty computation then it seems it would confirm this.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think actually you want to look at post-fork code and see if they have a conditional, or if the formula is just `x + 200000`.  If it is just a formula with a 200,000 block constant, it means you can have the code in from genesis.

author: potuz
content: I think they already know that they can have the code from genesis, I think Peter is really only asking for historical background

author: pipermerriam
content: Right.  If they take a look at the go-ethereum code that would have been running at genesis, they can see whether the rule was present or not.  Additional verification would be found if they look at the subsequent commits between genesis and the release prior to block 200000 and see that it was added.  This would in my view, verify/confirm the comment peter is asking about above.
